tossups.question: A procedure called iPOND [eye-pond] is used to study this process’s namesake stress response, which can be induced by the compound aphidicolin. All eukaryotes carry out this process using a complex of the proteins GINS [jins], MCM2 [M-C-M-two], and Cdc45 [C-D-C-forty-five]. In E. coli, this process initiates at a locus called oriC [or-ee-C], which is rich in (*) A–T base pairs. Kary Mullis pioneered a technique in which this process is performed with an enzyme from Thermus aquaticus. In this process, which is always in the 5-prime to 3-prime direction, ligase carries out discontinuous assembly by joining Okazaki fragments. For 10 points, name the process in which new strands are synthesized by DNA polymerase.
tossups.answer: DNA replication [or DNA synthesis; prompt on PCR or polymerase chain reaction] <RY, Biology>

tossups.question: Music borrowed from “Funeral Music in memory of Rikard Nordraak” was used in Grieg’s sonata for this instrument, his largest chamber work. Frederic Chopin’s only sonata not written for piano was written for this instrument. Beethoven’s five sonatas for this instrument were recorded in their entirety by Mischa Maisky [MY-skee]. Like a larger instrument, this instrument often requires an (*) endpin stop. A Catalan performer is largely responsible for the six technically demanding suites for this instrument by J. S. Bach. Its prominent players include Mstislav Rostropovich and Pablo Casals. For 10 points, name this low string instrument played by Silk Road Ensemble member Yo-Yo Ma.
tossups.answer: cello [or violoncello] <EX, Music>

tossups.question: A child of immigrants from this country judges a “leg contest” for teenage boys at a summer camp in Hungary. Maureen Freely translates works from this country, including a book describing the hüzün [hue-ZUNE], or melancholy, of the author’s home city. A man has himself shot at a performance of the play The Spanish Tragedy in this country. A lawyer in this country searches for his lost wife Ruya in the novel The Black Book. A poet here finds out that a (*) revolutionary named Blue had an affair with his lover, Ipek. Ka is a journalist who investigates suicides in this country’s city of Kars. For 10 points, name this home country of the author of Snow, Orhan Pamuk.
tossups.answer: Turkey [or Türkiye Cumhuriyeti] (The lead-in is from The Idiot by Elif Batuman) <RY, LongFic>

tossups.question: The amount of this phenomenon in industry contexts may be measured by the Grubel–Lloyd index. Increasing returns to scale in this phenomenon produce the home-market effect. Paul Krugman critiqued a model of this phenomenon from the Stockholm school that explains it as resulting from factor endowments. This phenomenon is nonexistent in a fully autarkic economy. (*) Leontief’s paradox critiques a model of it named for Heckscher and Ohlin. “Gains” from this phenomenon result from lower opportunity costs of production according to the principle of comparative advantage, which David Ricardo illustrated with Portuguese wine and English cloth. For 10 points, identify this phenomenon of economic exchange.
tossups.answer: international trade [prompt on comparative advantage or exchange until read] <LS, SocSci>

tossups.question: This country’s National Film Board adapted an iconic short story touching on linguistic conflict into the film The Sweater. It’s not Belgium, but conflict over separate schools for Catholics and Protestants in this country led to the downfall of a conservative government in an 1896 election, allowing a liberal Catholic to be elected its leader. A traditionally Catholic region of this country was secularized in the (*) 1960s by the “Quiet Revolution.” This country’s 1867 constitution made it officially bilingual. One of its leaders attempted to defuse regional independence movements with the Meech Lake Accord. For 10 points, name this country where tensions between English and French speakers have existed in Quebec.
tossups.answer: Canada <WA, OtherHist>

tossups.question: This phenomenon can be induced by heating a material above the Curie point, applying a large electric field, and then cooling it in the poling process. A converse version of this phenomenon, as predicted by Gabriel Lippman, was observed in cellulose and is also exploited in actuators. Paul Langevin used materials that exhibit this phenomenon to make an ultrasonic transducer for submarines. The (*) Curie brothers found Rochelle salt to exhibit a strong form of this phenomenon and used another material to develop an electrometer using this phenomenon. Modern crystal radio earpieces use materials that exhibit this phenomenon. Some clocks use quartz crystals as batteries since quartz exhibits this phenomenon. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which mechanical stress causes the buildup of electric charge.
tossups.answer: piezoelectricity [or piezoelectric effect] <JL, Phys>

tossups.question: A poem about these animals states that a man’s “tongue shall be filled with praise” because he follows them. In another poem, the speaker asks if this animal was seen on “England’s pleasant pastures” after asking if “those feet in ancient time / Walked upon England’s mountains.” This animal makes “all the vales rejoice” with its “tender voice” in another poem, which remarks on its (*) “clothing of delight.” In that poem, this animal is seen “by the stream and o’er the mead” and called “meek and mild” before the poem proclaims “God bless thee!” For 10 points, what animal is asked “Dost thou know who made thee?” in a William Blake poem that is often contrasted with “The Tyger”?
tossups.answer: lamb [accept Lamb of God; accept sheep] <JM, Poetry>

tossups.question: One of the first uses of color printing was to publish an art book from this country titled Manual of the Mustard Seed Garden. A decommissioned military factory in this country is the site of its 798 Art Zone. The “meticulous” style of painting in this country is often contrasted with a looser tradition that originated here, called “ink and wash.” Artists from this country were the first to be labeled as a “Southern School” and often worked in a style named for (*) mountains and rivers. In the 19th century, artists from a nearby country often produced illustrations of a classical tale from this country about 108 bandits. This country’s most iconic medieval painting depicts a harvest festival taking place along a river. For 10 points, name this country whose art frequently depicted the Yellow and Yangtze rivers.
tossups.answer: China [or People’s Republic of China; or Zhongguo] <EX, Painting>

tossups.question: This war is the subject of a history written at the age of 28 by historian Veronica Wedgwood. Alexander Leslie left this war to contest Scotland’s Bishops Wars after he had repelled a siege at Stralsund. A leader in this war gave up the Edict of Restitution, which attempted to restore the rule of “ecclesiastical reservation.” This war was ended by a treaty signed at (*) Osnabruck and Munster, which established a namesake doctrine of sovereignty in international law. This war, which had “Danish” and “Swedish” phases, began when Ferdinand II’s officials were defenestrated in Prague. For 10 points, the Peace of Westphalia ended what war that devastated Europe between 1618 and 1648?
tossups.answer: Thirty Years’ War <RY, ContHist>

tossups.question: Al-Ghazali conceived of these things as only being able to gain attributes through ‘arad [UH-rahd] or “accidents” of God’s intent. A different notion of these things posits that they exist along with kenon and was created by the “laughing philosopher.” Free will exists due to the clinamen [KLIH-nah-men] or “swerve” of these things according to On the Nature of Things by (*) Lucretius. They are contrasted with “corpuscules” because the latter form part of an infinite reality and thus cannot be split. According to Epicurus, all existence consisted of the void and these. This word’s use in the modern scientific sense was promoted by John Dalton. For 10 points, Democritus thought that the universe was made of what indivisible units, which in real life are divisible into nucleons and electrons?
tossups.answer: atoms [do not accept or prompt on “substances” or “monads”] <WA, PhilO>

tossups.question: One of these objects is compared to the tongue of the death god Yama. Abaris the Hyperborean travelled the world with one of these objects that gave him the powers of healing, levitation, and invisibility. In another story, nine of these objects are used lower the temperature of ancient China. A snake bite incapacitated the owner of some of these weapons, who was later retrieved from (*) Lemnos during the Trojan War. Philoctetes owned some of these weapons, one of which was used to kill Ravana from far away. A folk hero who used these weapons was often accompanied by companions such as Little John and Friar Tuck. For 10 points, name these sharp projectiles that Cupid used to make people fall in love.
tossups.answer: arrows [or bows] <VC, Myth>

tossups.question: Efforts to help people after one of these events were thwarted by the Gang of Four, whose members said that denouncing Deng Xiaoping affected 800 million lives, which was more important than “a few hundred thousand deaths.” Many yaodongs were wiped out in the “Jiajing” one of these events that took place in 1556. One of these events in 1137 was conflated with an 1139 one in Ganjak by later writers such as al-Taghribi, who wrote that 230,000 people died in northern Mesopotamia and (*) Aleppo from that one. The deadliest one of these in history struck Shaanxi province during the Ming dynasty. Events of this type destroyed the Colossus of Rhodes and caused a nuclear accident at Fukushima Daiichi. For 10 points, name these natural disasters, one of which flattened Lisbon in 1755.
tossups.answer: earthquakes [prompt on tsunamis] <WA, WorldHist>

tossups.question: A Knudsen cell can be employed to measure low values of this quantity in solids. This quantity, which can be measured using an isoteniscope, is higher than normal for a convex-curved droplet. Two substances with equal values for this quantity are linearly related with respect to their temperature on a Duhring plot. The log of this quantity can be set equal to “A minus B over C plus T” in (*) Antoine’s equation. Substances with higher values of it are considered more volatile. This quantity’s “partial” form is calculated by multiplying it with a mole fraction value in Raoult’s law. A sample reaches its boiling point when this quantity equals the atmospheric pressure. For 10 points, identify this quantity, the pressure of a gas in equilibrium.
tossups.answer: vapor pressure [accept vapor after “pressure” is read] <SB, Chem>

tossups.question: In a tondo by this sculptor, an infant St. John the Baptist holds a fluttering bird in his hand while the baby Jesus turns back to look at him. Australian geologist Laszlo Toth significantly damaged one sculpture by this artist after hammering away at it while proclaiming himself to be Jesus Christ arisen. Vasari praised this artist as “supreme not in one art alone, but in all three.” Statues of Rachel and Leah flank both sides of another sculpture by this man, which features (*) horns atop its head; that depiction of a “horned” Moses is in the middle of this sculptor’s tomb for Julius II. This man’s most famous sculpture holds a sling across his right shoulder and is depicting the moment before he is to face Goliath. For 10 points, name this Italian sculptor of David.
tossups.answer: Michelangelo di Ludovico Buonarotti Simoni [accept either underlined portion] <SB, OVisArt>

tossups.question: The book Seven Types of Ambiguity cites this writer’s construction “the A and B of C,” as in the sentence “Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness,” describing why a deputy is so strict. An essay about this writer states “The end of writing is to instruct; the end of poetry is to instruct by pleasing.” A children’s book of “Tales from” this writer was created by Mary and Charles Lamb. A preface to his edited works was written by Samuel (*) Johnson. Thomas de Quincey wrote an essay “On the Knocking at the Gate” in a play by this man, in which a speech beginning “Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow” is the source of William Faulkner’s title The Sound and the Fury. For 10 points, the First Folio collects the works of what Englishman nicknamed “the Bard?”
tossups.answer: William Shakespeare <RY, OtherLit>

tossups.question: An unfinished castle that is now a tourist attraction in this country was built by the Scottish plantation owner William Kellie. That castle is near a city that is home to a historic street called Concubine Lane and to many buildings and an airport named after Azlan Shah. Northam Road is a commercial hub in a city in this country founded by Francis Light. This Asian country’s second largest city, George Town, was founded by the British East India Company on (*) Penang Island. From 1998 to 2004, the world’s tallest building was one that César Pelli designed for this country’s oil company Petronas. For 10 points, name this country whose capital is Kuala Lumpur.
tossups.answer: Malaysia <RY, Geo>

tossups.question: A case about a law concerning these places resulted in a legal doctrine described as a “ghoul in a late night horror movie” from Antonin Scalia. 72 Nobel-winning scientists signed briefs in support of Don Aguillard in a 1987 case regarding these places. A fourth amendment violation in one of these places was alleged by the plaintiff in New Jersey v. TLO. A Pennsylvania law about some of them was declared unconstitutional in a case that created a three-pronged “test.” The case (*) Engel v. Vitale regarded application of the First Amendment to these places, as did a case whose defendants black armbands to protest of the Vietnam War. For 10 points, identify these places that were the subject of the cases Tinker v. Des Moines and Lemon v. Kurtzman, the latter of which concerned their “Catholic” variety.
tossups.answer: public schools [accept high schools; do not accept or prompt on “universities” since none of these are universities] <LS, AmHist>

tossups.question: As an infant, a boy in this city is conditioned to fear cans of Pabst Blue Ribbon and issues of The Economist in a version of the “Little Albert” experiment conducted by his psychologist father. A costume designer befriends a former hotel manager who came to this city from Iowa to escape his memory of Romola Martin. The city of Dickens is an “agrarian ghetto” of this metropolis where the protagonist reinstates segregation and slavery in (*) Paul Beatty’s novel The Sellout. A character who intends to paint a masterpiece titled “The Burning of” this city witnesses a riot started by Homer Simpson. For 10 points, what city is the setting of Nathanael West’s The Day of the Locust, an example of a “Hollywood novel”?
tossups.answer: Los Angeles [or LA; accept Dickens, California until “Iowa” is read] <RY, LongFic>

tossups.question: If mutations occurred in response to environmental stimulus, the Luria–Delbruck experiment would have shown this distribution of survivors. This distribution is the CDF of the exponential distribution. The square-root-of-n noise in particle detectors and telescopes is a result of this distribution of particle arrivals. Events like deaths by horse-kick and (*) radioactive decay, which are rare, are modeled by this distribution. Its namesake also names a continuous analog of the Bernoulli process whose point density follows this discrete distribution, which gives the probability of observing a number of independent events of a known rate in a given time period. For 10 points, identify this probability distribution function named for a Frenchman.
tossups.answer: Poisson [pwah-SAHN] distribution <JL, Math>

tossups.question: In Psalm 2, worshippers are instructed to serve the Lord with fear and do this to his son. Rabbi Akiva praised the ancient Medes for performing this act with their hands. An object called the osculatorium or pax was the subject of this action in early churches as part of a ritual for peace. Jesus gives the response “Friend, do what you are here to do” to an instance of this action. Because of massive crowds, it is often no longer possible to do this to the (*) Black Stone while on hajj. Medieval Europeans believed that witches greeted the Devil by doing this to his buttocks. A man was bribed to do this specific act to another man in a garden for the price of thirty pieces of silver. For 10 points, name this affectionate action that Judas Iscariot famously did to Jesus after betraying him.
tossups.answer: kiss [or equivalents; prompt on touch] <VC, Rel> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: These materials are typically the sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids. For 10 points each:
answers: hydrolysis [or hydrolyzation; accept word forms like hydrolyze or hydrolyzing]
parts: Name these materials that can be formed from animal fat and lye in the process of saponification. The long fatty acid hydrocarbon tails enable these materials to bind to hydrophobic dirt particles.

In saponification, fatty acid esters undergo this process, the opposite of a condensation reaction. In this process the namesake molecule is added to break C–O or P–O bonds, as in the creation of ADP from ATP.

This scientist’s equation determines the enthalpy of hydrolysis. His namesake diagrams are series of oxidation states connected by arrows that are labeled with the standard reduction potential between the diagrams, which are then used to construct Frost diagrams.

bonuses.leadin: In John Vanbrugh’s The Relapse, Colley Cibber played a lord who is named after this type of character in English drama. For 10 points each:
answers: fop (Lord Foppington appears in The Relapse, and Sir Fopling Flutter appears in The Man of Mode.)
The Way of the World <JM, Drama>
parts: Name this character type that also names the protagonist of Etherege’s The Man of Mode. It refers to a man who is overly concerned with his appearance.

Fops are stock characters in England’s comedy of manners. French works that could be described as comedies of manners include ones by this French playwright of The Misanthrope and The School for Wives.
William Congreve wrote this Restoration comedy about the witty lovers Mirabell and Millamant, who attempt to trick the bitter Lady Wishfort into an engagement with Sir Rowland.

bonuses.leadin: Ancient Greek and Chinese sources give this city’s name as Saketa. For 10 points each:
answers: Ayodhya [do not accept or prompt on “Ayutthaya”]
Laos [or Lao People’s Democratic Republic] <AF, WorldHist>
parts: Name this [emphasize] non-Southeast Asian city, which is the home of the hero of both Thailand’s national epic Ramakien and the Khmer epic Reamker [ree-um-KAY]. It lends its name to an early modern Thai kingdom.

Ayodhya lends its name to Ayutthaya [ah-yoo-tah-YAH], whose ruler Naresuan defeated Prince Mingyi Swa of the Toungoo Dynasty in a duel on the back of one of these animals. Often guided by howdahs, they are a common symbol of power in Southeast Asia.
The Lan Xang [lahn sahng] kingdom, whose name refers to a million elephants, was based in this modern-day country where evidence of ancient trade is found on the Plain of Jars.

bonuses.leadin: You are an opera singer. For 10 points each:
answers: arias [DO NOT reveal otherwise, but accept specific types like coloratura arias]
parts: The bulk of your showpieces are these sorts of expressive melodies for a single voice. Examples include “Nessun dorma” from Turandot and “O mio babbino caro” from Gianni Schicchi [JAH-nee SKEE-kee].

The arias you perform are interspersed with passages of this type, which use the cadence and rhythm of ordinary speech. Its secco, or unaccompanied, type comprises the bulk of Claudio Monteverdi’s operas.
You may perform complex arias written for this style of singing that uses virtuosic trills, tremolos, leaps, vibrato, and other enhancements. It is used by the title character of Lakmé.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Gary Fine’s ethnography of Dungeons and Dragons players – Shared Fantasy: Role Playing Games as Social Worlds. For 10 points each:
parts: Fine’s book asks “When was the first fantasy game played?” in discussing how rule-stretching led to paradigm shifts in gaming, and credits this author of The Structure of Scientific Revolutions with inspiring his analysis.
Fine borrows the term “voluntary subjection” from this author, who described that process as a necessary condition of play in the book Homo Ludens.

Fine’s book focuses on the sociology of D&D players, unlike later psychological studies of them, which generally considered their players to be exhibiting this form of variation from social norms. Émile Durkheim argued that anomie causes this.

bonuses.leadin: Locals in this country called harkis fought as irregular troops on the side of the French. For 10 points each:
answers: (People’s Democratic Republic of) Algeria [or Algérie; or al-Jaza’ir]
pied-noirs [pyay-nwarr] [accept black feet or black foots] <WA, ContHist>
parts: Name this North African country and former French colony, which gained independence in the 1960s under the leadership of the FLN.
This 1962 agreement brought an end to the violence in Algeria and granted it independence.
This name was given to Algerians of French descent who fled the colony and returned to France during and after Algeria’s war for independence.

bonuses.leadin: You are a corporation attempting to dodge taxes – legally, of course. For 10 points each:
answers: The Netherlands [or Holland; or Nederlands; accept Dutch disease]
parts: An easy way to do this in the US is to simply incorporate in this state, like most US corporations. This Atlantic state comprises most of the Delmarva peninsula.

Before 2015, you might have used a scheme called a “Double Irish” with a “sandwich” in this country, where you would locate a shell corporation. The demonym for this country names a “disease” that is equivalent to the widely-identified “resource curse.”

You’ve also got your eyes on this territory, whose statutory corporate tax rate of 10 percent has led it to have 60,000 registered corporations – two for every resident. It is also home to a growing population of Barbary macaques.

bonuses.leadin: The former captain of this vessel was killed after its front fell off and killed him. For 10 points each:
answers: the Virgin Mary [or Our Lady of Guadalupe; prompt on Mary] <VC, Myth>
parts: Name this ship that had a prow made from the oak at the sacred oracle of Dodona. It ferried Jason and his crew in their quest for the Golden Fleece.

Oak trees were sacred to many European thunder gods, such as this chief of the Slavic pantheon. This god’s axe, which always returned to his hand, is a major symbol of the pre-Christian Slavic religion.

Folk beliefs about oak trees, such as one located near Tervuren in Belgium, often grew to include this figure as a healer and miraculous benefactor. After appearing to Juan Diego, this person may have been syncretized with the mythic figure Tonantzin.

bonuses.leadin: The cells that make these proteins can undergo isotype switching to change part of their heavy chains, for example switching from IgM to IgG. For 10 points each:
answers: rheumatoid arthritis [or RA; prompt on arthritis]
parts: What proteins, also called immunoglobulins, are produced by plasma cells as part of the immune response?
Antibodies found in this disease include anti-CCP antibodies and this disease’s namesake factor. This autoimmune disease mostly affects the joints.
In RA, the protein DKK-1 is overexpressed, causing inhibition of these signaling pathways. They are named for a family of proteins that bind to Frizzled receptors and activate beta-catenin.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, a student boils and steps on the title object to make it shrink, after which its owner feels as satisfied as if he had copied out the Lotus Sutra. For 10 points each:
answers: Romance of the Three Kingdoms [or Sanguo Yanyi] <RY, Short>
parts: Name this story about Father Zenchi, a priest who needs someone to accompany him with a two-foot-long stick whenever he eats.
“The Nose” is a story by this Japanese writer of short stories like “The Spider’s Thread,” “In a Grove,” and “Rashomon.”
In “The Nose,” Father Zenchi compares himself to Liu Bei [loo bay], a character from this 14th-century Chinese novel about the wars at the end of the Han dynasty.

bonuses.leadin: A “messy” variety of these algorithms was developed by David Goldberg, who proposed that they work via a “building blocks hypothesis.” For 10 points each:
answers: they are locally optimum [or local optimum solutions; or local extrema; or local extremum; or local maximum or local minimum; prompt on local solutions; accept descriptive answers like “they are not globally maximal”] <WA, CompSci>
parts: Identify these algorithms that use a “fitness function” to estimate how close they are to finding a solution.
Genetic algorithms take their inspiration from the theory of this process by natural selection, as outlined by Charles Darwin in On the Origin of Species.

Though often superior to hill-climbing algorithms, genetic algorithms often face similar problems because the solutions they find typically have this property. Basin hopping methods aim to avoid solutions with this property.

bonuses.leadin: A “hedonic calculus” was invented to help apply this philosophy. For 10 points each:
answers: Peter Singer [or Peter Albert David Singer]
Sam Harris [or Samuel Benjamin Harris] <WA, PhilO>
parts: Name this ethical philosophy, whose central goal is “the greatest good for the greatest number.” Its famous advocates include Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill.
This contemporary philosopher and author of Practical Ethics advocates that utilitarianism be applied to animals as well as humans. He wrote Animal Liberation.

Several critics, such as Kwame Appiah, have said that this nonreligious author’s attempt to create a science-based ethics in The Moral Landscape is basically a re-hashing of utilitarianism. This advocate of Dzogchen meditation also wrote book-length essays titled Lying and Free Will.

bonuses.leadin: This man may have coined the phrase “speak truth to power,” having co-authored a pamphlet with that title for the American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker activist group. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this civil rights leader who, with A. Philip Randolph, organized the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

This state’s Senator Strom Thurmond called Rustin a “Communist, draft-dodger, and homosexual,” having Rustin’s arrest record entered into the Congressional Record. William Tecumseh Sherman devastated its state capital of Columbia.
Thurmond’s “Dixiecrat” party, which he led during a presidential run, was officially called by a name combining this two-word concept with “Democratic Party.”

bonuses.leadin: This poem’s speaker describes people with foreign-sounding names like Mr. Silvero, Hakagawa, Madame de Tornquist, and Fraulein von Kulp. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem about a man whose “small deliberations” are able to “multiply variety / In a wilderness of mirrors.” It begins “Here I am, an old man in a dry month.”
T.S. Eliot, the author of “Gerontion”, wrote this long poem that opens “April is the cruelest month” and ends with the words “Shantih shantih shantih”.
Like Eliot, this Irish poet wrote a book about the legendary Mad King Sweeney. He created a 1999 translation of Beowulf, and collected his own poems in Death of a Naturalist.

bonuses.leadin: The bandoneón [bon-doh-nay-OWN] was adapted for use in this style of music’s “new” form by one of its composers. For 10 points each:
answers: harp [accept concert harp; accept Paraguayan harp or arpa] <EX, Music>
parts: Name this type of music that is oddly popular in Finland. Pablo Ziegler played in the Conjunto 9 [cone-HOON-toh nweh-vay] collection of musicians in this style in the 1970s.
Astor Piazzolla, the preeminent composer of nuevo tango, lived in this modern-day country whose other composers included Alberto Ginastera [hee-nah-STAIR-uh].

Ginastera wrote a 1965 concerto for the concert variety of this instrument, whose Paraguayan variety is played with the fingernails. The concert version of instrument uses seven pedals to alter the pitches of its strings.

bonuses.leadin: Louis IX of France led two of these campaigns, but was rather unlucky, being caught for ransom in one of them and dying in Tunisia during the other. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these expeditions, the first of which was called by Urban II at the Council of Clermont.

The kings of Jerusalem styled themselves defenders of this church, whose possession by “unclean nations” was noted in Urban II’s address. This church is believed to be the location of both Golgotha and Jesus’s tomb.

The last Crusader state to fall was the “County” named for this modern-day Lebanese city; the state was actually led from Tartus for the first seven years of its existence by Raymond IV, Count of Toulouse, and encompassed cities like Acre.

bonuses.leadin: For a particle in a box, the constant due to this process is square root of 2 over L. For 10 points each:
answers: normalization [do NOT accept or prompt on “renormalization”]
parts: Name this process, which is performed on wavefunctions to ensure that their integral of the square of their magnitude is one, allowing them to be used as probabilities.
Quantum mechanical systems are interpreted probabilistically in the interpretation developed by Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg in this Danish capital.

This rule states that you can only observe values for a property that are eigenvalues of the operator of that property. The probability of observing each eigenvalue is the magnitude of the wavefunction at that value squared.

bonuses.leadin: This term was first introduced by Ivan Turgenev to describe radical intellectual currents in Russia in the 19th century. For 10 points each:
answers: Yevgeny (Vasilevich) Bazarov [accept either underlined portion; or Eugene]
parts: Identify this philosophy, which holds that life has no meaning and there is no inherent morality.

Turgenev’s best-known nihilist character is this medical student and mentor of Arkady Kirsanov in Fathers and Sons. He defends ideas against Arkady’s landlord father Nikolai and is challenged to a duel by Pavel.
An example of the “anti-nihilistic” novel is No Way Out, a novel by this author who also wrote the story “The Steel Flea” and the novella Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk.

bonuses.leadin: After his disciples asked him why he used these things, Jesus responded, “Though seeing, they do not see; though hearing, they do not hear or understand.” For 10 points each:
answers: Parables of Jesus [prompt on Stories or similar answers]
parts: Name these teaching tools that include one about a Prodigal Son.

In his explanation, Jesus is apparently fulfilling this prophet’s similarly worded prophecy on using parables. This prophet may have also predicted John the Baptist in saying “A voice of one calling: ‘In the wilderness prepare the way for the LORD.’”
This term is believed to be used metonymically for Jesus in four “songs” in Isaiah. Kings and Princes will bow down to this person “who was despised and abhorred by the nations.”

bonuses.leadin: One of these individuals named Titus dressed “as a Monk” currently is shown in a painting hanging in the Rijksmuseum. For 10 points each:
answers: children of Rembrandt van Rijn [or sons of Rembrandt van Rijn]
parts: Identify these individuals. Titus was the only surviving member of this group and was shown in a red hat and a gold necklace by his father.
Rembrandt’s The Prodigal Son in the Tavern depicts the artist revelling, drink in hand, with this wife of his. Her death at 30 was depicted by Rembrandt in paintings of her sick bed.
This Rembrandt painting has survived knife slashings and acid splashings during its time at the Rijksmuseum. It depicts the shooting company of Frans Banning Cocq.
